choices.text: Motor supply to all intrinsic laryngeal muscles

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient undergoing thyroid surgery sustains injury to the external branch of the superior laryngeal nerve. Which of the following is most likely to be affected?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Tension of the vocal cords

 

Cricothyroid muscle, which controls tension of the vocal cords, is supplied by the external branch of the superior laryngeal nerve. Damage leads to inability to produce high-pitched sounds.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sensation above vocal cords: Supplied by the internal branch of the superior laryngeal nerve, not the external branch.

 

Option B. Sensation below vocal cords: Supplied by the recurrent laryngeal nerve, not related to the external branch.

 

Option C. Motor supply to all intrinsic laryngeal muscles: All intrinsic muscles except cricothyroid are supplied by the recurrent laryngeal nerve.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The cricothyroid muscle, which tenses the vocal cords, is supplied by the external branch of the superior laryngeal nerve.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg. 298

choices.text: It supplies all intrinsic muscles of the larynx
It arises higher in the neck than the right nerve
It has a shorter course than the right nerve
It loops around the aortic arch and has a longer intrathoracic course

questions.text: Which of the following statements best explains why the left recurrent laryngeal nerve is more prone to injury or paralysis than the right?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) It loops around the aortic arch and has a longer intrathoracic course

 

This longer course in the mediastinum makes the left recurrent laryngeal nerve more susceptible to injury from thoracic pathologies (e.g., aortic aneurysm, mediastinal tumors).

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It supplies all intrinsic muscles of the larynx: True for both recurrent laryngeal nerves, but does not explain the higher susceptibility of the left nerve.

 

Option B. It arises higher in the neck than the right nerve: Incorrect. In fact, the left arises lower, from the thorax.


Option C. It has a shorter course than the right nerve: Incorrect. The left recurrent laryngeal nerve has a longer course as it loops around the aortic arch in the thorax.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The left recurrent laryngeal nerve is more prone to paralysis due to its longer intrathoracic course, looping around the aortic arch.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 298

choices.text: Its internal branch supplies motor innervation to the cricothyroid muscle
It arises from the superior cervical ganglion
The internal branch pierces the cricothyroid membrane to enter the larynx
The external branch provides motor supply to the cricothyroid muscle

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the superior laryngeal nerve is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans D) The external branch provides motor supply to the cricothyroid muscle

 

This branch controls pitch modulation by tensing the vocal cords via the cricothyroid muscle.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Its internal branch supplies motor innervation to the cricothyroid muscle:. Incorrect. The external branch is motor; the internal branch is sensory.

 

Option B. It arises from the superior cervical ganglion: Incorrect. It arises from the inferior ganglion of the vagus nerve, not from the sympathetic chain.

 

Option C. The internal branch pierces the cricothyroid membrane to enter the larynx: Incorrect. The internal branch pierces the thyrohyoid membrane, not the cricothyroid membrane.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The external branch of the superior laryngeal nerve provides motor innervation to the cricothyroid muscle, while the internal branch supplies sensory innervation to the larynx above the vocal cords.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 298

choices.text: Isolated vocal cord paralysis without any other cranial nerve involvement
High vagal lesion at jugular foramen
Involvement of other cranial nerves and long tract signs
Lead toxicity as the most likely cause

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presents with hoarseness of voice for 2 months. On examination, he is found to have unilateral vocal cord paralysis. MRI of the brain shows a lesion involving the nucleus ambiguus. Which of the following is the most likely associated finding in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans C) Involvement of other cranial nerves and long tract signs

 

The nucleus ambiguus is located in the medulla, and lesions here (nuclear lesions) often affect multiple cranial nerves (IX, X, XI) and may be associated with long tract signs due to their close anatomical proximity.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Incorrect: Isolated vocal cord paralysis is more commonly seen in low vagal or recurrent laryngeal nerve lesions, not in nuclear causes.

 

Option B. Incorrect: Lesion at the jugular foramen represents a high vagal lesion, not a nuclear lesion in the medulla.

 

Option D. Incorrect:Lead poisoning is a systemic cause of laryngeal paralysis but is not specifically related to a nuclear lesion involving the nucleus ambiguus.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Nuclear causes of laryngeal paralysis involve the nucleus ambiguus in the medulla and are commonly associated with other cranial nerve palsies and long tract involvement.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 298

choices.text: CT scan of the brain
MRI of the cervical spine
Chest X-ray followed by bronchoscopy

questions.text: A 55-year-old chronic smoker presents with hoarseness of voice for 3 months. Flexible laryngoscopy reveals a left vocal cord in the paramedian position that fails to abduct on deep inspiration. There is no evidence of recent surgery. Which of the following should be the next best investigation to rule out a serious cause?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Chest X-ray followed by bronchoscopy

 

Left recurrent laryngeal nerve loops around the aortic arch in the chest. Hence, bronchogenic carcinoma is a crucial cause of left-sided vocal cord paralysis. A chest X-ray followed by bronchoscopy and biopsy is essential to rule it out.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CT scan of the brain: Not the first choice in evaluation of isolated vocal cord paralysis. Brain lesions causing vocal cord paralysis are rare (supranuclear causes) and typically involve multiple cranial nerves.

 

Option B. MRI of the cervical spine: May be useful in neurogenic causes or compressive lesions in the neck, but less useful than chest imaging for suspected bronchogenic carcinoma.

 

Option D. Indirect laryngoscopy under GA: Already evaluated with flexible laryngoscopy. Further laryngeal visualization is not required unless a surgical procedure is planned.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Unilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve paralysis with paramedian cord position warrants chest imaging to rule out bronchogenic carcinoma—especially on the left side.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 299

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with hoarseness of voice, dysphagia, and nasal regurgitation. On examination, there is paralysis of the vocal cord along with deviation of the uvula and loss of gag reflex on the same side. These findings suggest a high vagal nerve lesion. Which of the following is the most likely cause if the lesion is located at the skull base?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Basal skull fracture

 

A well-known cause of high vagal lesions at the skull base, where cranial nerves IX, X, and XI traverse the jugular foramen. This explains multiple lower cranial nerve palsies in this patient.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A – Tumour of posterior cranial fossa: This is a cause of intracranial high vagal lesion, not skull base. It can compress multiple cranial nerves but is not specific to skull base involvement.

 

Option B – Glomus tumour: Typically arises from paraganglia in the neck, especially at the jugular foramen or carotid body, hence a cause of neck-level lesion.

 

Option D – Tracheal stenosis: Not related to vagal nerve lesions. It may cause respiratory symptoms but does not cause cranial nerve deficits.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Basal skull fractures involving the jugular foramen can cause high vagal lesions presenting as combined paralysis of lower cranial nerves.
 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 299

choices.text: Teflon injection into the vocal cord

questions.text: A 50-year-old male underwent thyroid surgery 3 months ago. He now presents with mild hoarseness of voice but no aspiration or breathing difficulty. Flexible laryngoscopy shows a left vocal cord in paramedian position with partial compensation by the right cord. What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Observation and voice therapy

 

Since many patients compensate over time and temporary paralysis may recover within 6–12 months, waiting and supportive therapy is appropriate. Gelfoam/fat injection may be considered if voice is significantly impaired during this period.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Teflon injection into the vocal cord: Not preferred currently due to foreign body reaction and stiffness. It was used previously for permanent medialization.

Option B. Immediate Type I thyroplasty: Type I thyroplasty is for persistent symptoms and posterior glottic incompetence. It is not indicated immediately, especially when spontaneous recovery is possible in 6–12 months.

Option D. Arytenoid adduction surgery: Reserved for cases where posterior glottis is also incompetent and medialization is inadequate with thyroplasty alone. Not the first-line approach in early or mild unilateral paralysis.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Most cases of unilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve paralysis improve spontaneously and are managed conservatively for the first 6–12 months.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 299

choices.text: Complete paralysis of both recurrent and superior laryngeal nerves
Isolated recurrent laryngeal nerve paralysis
Paralysis of adductor muscles of the larynx

questions.text: A patient with suspected vocal cord paralysis undergoes laryngoscopy. The right vocal cord is observed to be fixed 1.5 mm from the midline. Which of the following conditions most likely explains this position?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Isolated recurrent laryngeal nerve paralysis

 

Recurrent laryngeal nerve innervates all intrinsic muscles except cricothyroid. When it's paralyzed, the cord assumes a paramedian position (1.5 mm from midline) because the cricothyroid (via the superior laryngeal nerve) keeps some medial tension.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Complete paralysis of both recurrent and superior laryngeal nerves: This causes the vocal cord to rest in the intermediate (cadaveric) position (3.5 mm from midline), not the paramedian.

 

Option C. Normal quiet respiration: In quiet breathing, cords are in gentle abduction (7 mm)—not paramedian.

 

Option D. Paralysis of adductor muscles of the larynx: Leads to abducted position of the cord, closer to 7–9.5 mm, depending on whether respiration is quiet or deep.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Paramedian position of the vocal cord (1.5 mm from midline) indicates isolated recurrent laryngeal nerve paralysis.
 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 299

choices.text: Carcinoma of the right lung apex
Cervical lymphadenopathy on the right side

questions.text: A 65-year-old chronic smoker presents with hoarseness of voice for 2 months. On flexible laryngoscopy, the left vocal cord is found in the paramedian position and immobile. Which of the following conditions must be ruled out first in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Bronchogenic carcinoma

 

The left RLN loops around the arch of aorta and has a longer intrathoracic course, making it more susceptible to compression by bronchogenic carcinoma, especially from the left side of the mediastinum.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Carcinoma of the right lung apex: This is a known cause of right RLN palsy, not left. The right RLN loops around the subclavian artery and is more superficial.

 

Option B. Thyroid surgery history: A relevant cause but usually bilateral or unilateral depending on side. In this question, smoking and mediastinal involvement point toward a pulmonary cause as first priority.

 

Option D. Cervical lymphadenopathy on the right side: Could cause right RLN paralysis but does not explain isolated left vocal cord paralysis in this clinical context.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Left recurrent laryngeal nerve paralysis in a smoker mandates ruling out bronchogenic carcinoma due to its long intrathoracic course.
 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 299

choices.text: Bilateral abductor palsy (bilateral RLN paralysis)

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with progressive shortness of breath and noisy breathing, especially during exertion. She has a normal voice. History reveals recent thyroid surgery. Flexible laryngoscopy shows both vocal cords lying in a paramedian position and immobile during respiration. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Bilateral abductor palsy (bilateral RLN paralysis)

 

Post-thyroidectomy bilateral RLN injury can cause paralysis of all intrinsic laryngeal muscles except cricothyroid, leading to cords lying in median or paramedian position. This results in good voice (adductors intact) but severe stridor and dyspnoea, especially on exertion.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A – Bilateral vocal cord nodules: Incorrect. Nodules cause hoarseness due to improper cord closure, but not stridor or dyspnoea. Voice is affected, not respiration.

 

 

Option C. Laryngomalacia: Incorrect. Typically presents in infants, not adults. It causes inspiratory stridor since the supraglottic structures collapse during inspiration.

 

 

Option D. Acute laryngitis: Incorrect. Usually causes hoarseness or aphonia. Airway compromise is rare unless superimposed on another condition.

 

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Bilateral abductor paralysis due to recurrent laryngeal nerve injury causes stridor and dyspnoea with preserved voice due to cords fixed in median or paramedian position.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 300
questions.video_explanation_heading: BILATERAL RLN PALSY, BOTH CORDS NOT ABDUCTING DURING RESPIRATION

choices.text: Permanent tracheostomy with a speaking valve

questions.text: A 52-year-old male develops bilateral abductor vocal cord paralysis following total thyroidectomy. He presents with stridor and exertional dyspnoea but retains a good quality voice. Which of the following is the most appropriate definitive management to relieve airway obstruction without leaving a permanent tracheostomy stoma?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cordectomy with cord lateralization

 

A surgical procedure that lateralizes the vocal cord to improve airway. This relieves stridor but compromises voice to some extent. It avoids permanent tracheostomy, making it preferable in many long-standing cases.

       

Other Options:

 

Option A. Permanent tracheostomy with a speaking valve:Correct but not preferred. It is often required in emergencies or if lateralization surgery is not feasible. It maintains good voice but leaves a permanent stoma.

 

Option C. Recurrent laryngeal nerve anastomosis: Incorrect. Rarely successful in bilateral cases and not practical as definitive airway relief.

Option D. Injection laryngoplasty: Incorrect. Used in unilateral vocal cord paralysis to medialize the cord and improve phonation—not for relieving airway obstruction in bilateral abductor palsy.

Educational Objective: 

 

In long-standing bilateral abductor vocal cord paralysis, cord lateralization relieves airway obstruction without a permanent tracheostomy but compromises voice quality.
 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 300
questions.video_explanation_heading: LEFT KASHIMA (COBLATOR ASSISTED) DONE FOR B/L VC PALSY. ALSO FOLLOW-UP AT 6 MONTHS POST-OP IS SHOWN.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female presents with chronic exertional stridor following bilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve injury during thyroidectomy. Her voice remains fairly good. She refuses permanent tracheostomy and prefers an option that widens the airway through the larynx. Which of the following is the most appropriate endoscopic surgical procedure to relieve her airway obstruction?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Transverse cordotomy (Kashima operation)

 

This endoscopic procedure excises soft tissue at the junction of the membranous cord and vocal process using a laser to widen the airway. It is the preferred modern approach for bilateral abductor palsy, avoiding tracheostomy.

Other Options:

 

Option A. Type I Thyroplasty: Incorrect. Type I thyroplasty is a medialization procedure used in unilateral vocal cord palsy to improve voice, not to relieve airway in bilateral abductor paralysis.

 

 

 

Option C. Injection laryngoplasty: Incorrect. Also used for medialization in unilateral palsy, mainly to improve voice—not suitable for opening airway in bilateral paralysis.

 

 

Option D. Recurrent laryngeal nerve reanastomosis: Incorrect. These reinnervation procedures have shown limited success and are not first-line or definitive airway-widening strategies in bilateral cases.

Educational Objective: 

 

Transverse cordotomy (Kashima operation) is the preferred modern endoscopic procedure to relieve airway obstruction in bilateral abductor paralysis without the need for a permanent tracheostomy.
 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 300
questions.video_explanation_heading: SURGERY SHOWING LEFT KASHIMA FOR BILATERAL VOCAL PALSY ASSISTED BY COBLATOR

choices.text: Internal branch of superior laryngeal nerve
External branch of superior laryngeal nerve

questions.text: A professional singer presents with a weak voice and inability to reach high-pitched notes following thyroid surgery. Laryngoscopic examination reveals a wavy vocal cord with an askew glottis. Which of the following nerves is most likely injured?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) External branch of superior laryngeal nerve

 

This branch innervates the cricothyroid muscle, which tenses the vocal cord and is essential for high-pitched phonation. Damage leads to weak voice, loss of pitch, and askew glottis due to anterior commissure rotation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Recurrent laryngeal nerve: Incorrect. This nerve supplies all intrinsic laryngeal muscles except cricothyroid. Injury causes hoarseness due to abductor/adductor dysfunction, not primarily pitch-related issues.

 

Option B. Internal branch of superior laryngeal nerve:Incorrect. This branch is purely sensory and supplies mucosa above the vocal cords. Its injury causes loss of sensation, not loss of pitch control.

 

Option D. Glossopharyngeal nerve: Incorrect. This nerve is involved in oropharyngeal sensation and taste, not phonation or vocal cord function.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Injury to the external branch of the superior laryngeal nerve affects the cricothyroid muscle, leading to a weak voice, inability to raise pitch, and laryngoscopic signs like glottic asymmetry and wavy vocal cord.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 301

choices.text: Bilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve palsy
Bilateral superior laryngeal nerve palsy
Unilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve palsy
External branch of superior laryngeal nerve injury

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presents with persistent choking while eating, frequent bouts of coughing during swallowing, and a weak, husky voice. He has a recent history of cervical lymphadenopathy and was treated for diphtheria two months ago. Laryngoscopic examination reveals bilateral flaccid vocal cords and loss of protective airway reflexes. Which of the following best explains the clinical findings?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Bilateral superior laryngeal nerve palsy

 

Paralysis of both cricothyroid muscles leads to weak and husky voice. Bilateral sensory loss above vocal cords results in absence of protective reflexes, leading to aspiration of food and secretions, cough, and choking.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve palsy: Incorrect. This results in bilateral abductor paralysis with stridor and airway obstruction but voice is usually good. Aspiration is not a predominant symptom unless glottic incompetence is severe.

 

Option C. Unilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve palsy: Incorrect. Usually asymptomatic or mild hoarseness without aspiration. Does not cause bilateral symptoms like choking on both sides.

 

Option D. External branch of superior laryngeal nerve injury: Incorrect. Involves only the motor function to cricothyroid muscle on one side, leading to inability to raise pitch. No sensory deficit or aspiration.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Bilateral superior laryngeal nerve palsy causes weak voice and aspiration due to loss of cricothyroid function and bilateral sensory loss above the glottis.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 300

choices.text: Injection of teflon paste into the paralyzed cord

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman underwent total thyroidectomy for a multinodular goiter. Postoperatively, she complains of hoarseness and frequent aspiration of liquids. Laryngoscopic examination reveals the ipsilateral vocal cord lying in cadaveric position with glottic gap during phonation. What is the most appropriate next step in management if symptoms persist despite initial speech therapy?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Injection of teflon paste into the paralyzed cord

 

This is used to medialize the paralyzed cord to improve glottic closure and reduce aspiration. Though not preferred now due to possible foreign body reaction, it is still a valid management option if thyroplasty is not possible. It is done under local anesthesia using direct laryngoscopy.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Tracheostomy: Not indicated in this case as there is no airway obstruction. This is used in bilateral abductor palsy with airway compromise.

 

Option C. Thyroplasty type II: This procedure is used to lateralize the cords, typically for bilateral adductor paralysis, not for unilateral glottic incompetence.

 

 

Option D. Posterior cordotomy: This is used for widening the airway in bilateral abductor paralysis. It does not address hoarseness or aspiration.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Unilateral combined paralysis of the larynx (both recurrent and superior laryngeal nerves) results in glottic incompetence with hoarseness and aspiration, managed by medialization procedures like teflon injection or thyroplasty type I.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 301
questions.video_explanation_heading: VIDEOLARYNGOSCOPY SHOWING LEFT VC PALSY. RIGHT VC IS ABDUCTING DURING RESPIRATION AND ADDUCTING DURING PHONATION. LEFT VC IS NOT MOVING EITHER DURING RESPIRATION OR PHONATION.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male with advanced neck malignancy develops sudden aphonia, repeated episodes of aspiration, and ineffective cough. Flexible laryngoscopy reveals both vocal cords in cadaveric position. There is total anaesthesia of the larynx. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Tracheostomy with gastrostomy

 

This is the correct initial step in management to secure the airway (via tracheostomy) and prevent aspiration while maintaining nutrition (via gastrostomy). It is the first line in complete bilateral laryngeal paralysis with aspiration risk and aphonia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Thyroplasty type I: Aimed at medializing the paralyzed cord to improve voice in unilateral RLN paralysis. It is not useful here, as both cords are paralyzed and patient has aphonia with severe aspiration.

 

 

Option B. Vocal cord lateralization: Intended to improve airway in bilateral abductor paralysis, but this patient has aspiration and anaesthetic larynx, not airway compromise due to median cord position. Lateralization will worsen aspiration.

 

 

Option D. Arytenoidectomy with laser cordectomy: This improves airway in bilateral abductor palsy but does not address aspiration or loss of protective reflexes due to complete laryngeal anaesthesia. Not appropriate here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In bilateral complete laryngeal paralysis, tracheostomy with gastrostomy is essential to manage aspiration, aphonia, and ineffective cough due to glottic incompetence and laryngeal anaesthesia.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 301

choices.text: Congenital bilateral vocal cord paralysis

questions.text: A 5-day-old neonate presents with stridor and respiratory distress. Flexible laryngoscopy reveals immobile vocal cords in paramedian position bilaterally. MRI of the brain shows features of Arnold–Chiari malformation. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Congenital bilateral vocal cord paralysis

 

Bilateral vocal cord paralysis can be associated with CNS anomalies like Arnold–Chiari malformation, hydrocephalus, or agenesis of the nucleus ambiguus. Patients typically present with stridor, respiratory obstruction, and may require tracheostomy due to bilateral abductor palsy pattern.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Bilateral laryngomalacia: Commonest cause of congenital stridor, but the cords are mobile and the condition is due to supraglottic floppiness. Also, stridor typically improves in the prone position.

 

 

Option C. Subglottic stenosis: Can cause stridor, but there is no vocal cord immobility. Diagnosis is based on subglottic narrowing on endoscopy or imaging. Associated CNS anomalies are not typical.

 

 

Option D. Tracheoesophageal fistula: Presents with choking, coughing, and cyanosis during feeds, not stridor alone. Not associated with bilateral vocal cord immobility.

 

.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Congenital bilateral vocal cord paralysis is often associated with CNS malformations like Arnold–Chiari and presents with stridor and airway obstruction requiring tracheostomy.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 301

questions.text: A 38-year-old male with unilateral vocal cord paralysis complains of a weak, breathy voice. Flexible laryngoscopy shows the affected vocal cord in the paramedian position. He is not willing for injection therapy and opts for a permanent surgical procedure to improve his voice. Which of the following is the most appropriate surgical option?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Isshiki Type I Thyroplasty

 

Type I thyroplasty involves medialization of the paralyzed vocal cord to allow approximation by the healthy cord. It is the procedure of choice for unilateral vocal cord paralysis with breathy voice. Performed under local anesthesia using a window in the thyroid cartilage.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Isshiki Type II Thyroplasty: This involves lateralization of the vocal cord, used primarily for bilateral abductor palsy to improve airway, not for voice improvement.

 

 

Option C. Isshiki Type III Thyroplasty: This procedure shortens and relaxes the vocal cords to lower the pitch of the voice. Used in mutational falsetto or male gender affirmation surgery (female-to-male transformation).

 

 

Option D. Isshiki Type IV Thyroplasty: This lengthens and tightens the vocal cords to increase the pitch. Used in male-to-female gender transformation or in cases of bowed cords due to aging or trauma.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Isshiki Type I thyroplasty is the surgical treatment of choice for medialization of a paralyzed vocal cord in unilateral vocal cord paralysis.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 302

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presents with a breathy voice following a road traffic accident. Flexible laryngoscopy reveals unilateral vocal cord paralysis in the paramedian position. He is not willing for tracheostomy or thyroplasty and expresses interest in procedures that might restore nerve function to the laryngeal muscles. Which of the following surgical options is most appropriate in this scenario?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Laryngeal reinnervation with ansa hypoglossi

 

In this procedure, a segment of the omohyoid muscle, with its nerve supply from ansa hypoglossi, is implanted into the thyroarytenoid muscle via a window in the thyroid cartilage. It attempts to restore innervation to the paralyzed vocal cord.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Injection laryngoplasty with gelfoam: A temporary medialization procedure to improve voice quality while waiting for potential spontaneous recovery of vocal cord function. It does not restore nerve supply.

 

 

Option B. Isshiki Type I thyroplasty: A permanent medialization procedure using prosthesis, done under local anesthesia to improve voice. This too does not restore innervation but alters vocal cord position.

 

 

Option C. Laser cordectomy: Removal of part or whole of the vocal cord, typically used for airway improvement in bilateral abductor palsy or for early glottic carcinoma, not suitable for restoring nerve supply.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Laryngeal reinnervation using ansa hypoglossi is aimed at restoring nerve supply to the paralyzed vocal cord by implanting a nerve–muscle pedicle into the thyroarytenoid muscle.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 301

questions.text: A 24-year-old emotionally sensitive female presents with sudden loss of voice for the past 2 days. She is able to whisper but unable to produce sound while speaking. There is no history of upper respiratory infection, trauma, or vocal abuse. On laryngoscopic examination, the vocal cords are seen abducted and fail to move during phonation. However, the cords approximate normally during a voluntary cough. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Reassurance and psychotherapy

 

Correct. This is the mainstay of treatment in functional (psychogenic) aphonia. Patient needs to be reassured that the vocal cords are normal.

 

This is a classic case of Functional Aphony (Hysterical Aphony)—a psychogenic voice disorder common in emotionally labile females aged 15–30 years. The key feature is sudden-onset aphonia with preserved vocal cord adduction during cough, indicating intact motor function. No organic lesion is present.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Microlaryngoscopy with biopsy: Not indicated as there is no organic lesion suspected. Vocal cord mobility is normal during cough.

 

Option C. Voice rest with corticosteroids: Corticosteroids are not helpful in functional disorders. This would be more relevant in acute laryngitis or vocal cord edema.

 

Option D. Speech therapy for vocal nodules: There is no evidence of nodules or organic pathology on laryngoscopy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Functional aphonia is treated with reassurance and psychotherapy; diagnosis is confirmed by preserved vocal cord movement during cough despite aphonia.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 314

choices.text: Speech therapy with Gutzmann’s pressure technique

questions.text: A 17-year-old boy presents with complaints of persistent high-pitched voice despite having normal physical and sexual development. He is emotionally immature and socially withdrawn. On examination, there are no structural abnormalities of the larynx. Laryngoscopy shows elongated vocal cords with normal movement. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial management?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Speech therapy with Gutzmann’s pressure technique

 

This is the first-line and most effective treatment for puberphonia. It helps retrain the patient’s voice production.

 

 

This case is classic for Puberphonia, also called Mutational Falsetto, where a male fails to transition to a lower-pitched adult voice after puberty despite normal laryngeal development.

 

It is often associated with emotional immaturity, insecurity, and psychological reluctance to assume adult male roles. The larynx is normal, but the patient continues to use a high-pitched tone due to habitual misuse.

 

Treatment is voice therapy. Gutzmann’s pressure test is a simple technique where backward and downward pressure on the thyroid cartilage helps relax the cords and produce a lower-pitched voice, which is then trained and reinforced by the patient.

 

Other Options:

 

Opton B. Thyroplasty type I: Used in unilateral vocal cord paralysis, not in functional disorders like puberphonia.

Option C. Injection laryngoplasty: Indicated for glottic insufficiency or vocal cord paralysis—not functional voice disorders.

Option D. Microlaryngoscopic cord stripping: Indicated in cases like leukoplakia or carcinoma in situ, not in puberphonia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Puberphonia is treated by voice therapy using Gutzmann’s pressure technique to retrain the patient to produce a low-pitched adult male voice.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 314

choices.text: External branch of superior laryngeal nerve
Internal branch of superior laryngeal nerve

questions.text: A 50-year-old male underwent thyroid surgery for a large multinodular goiter. Postoperatively, he complains that he can no longer produce high-pitched sounds, especially while trying to sing. He does not report hoarseness or difficulty breathing. On laryngoscopic examination, the vocal cord movements are normal. Which of the following nerves is most likely injured?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) External branch of superior laryngeal nerve

 

It supplies the cricothyroid muscle, which is responsible for tension and pitch modulation of the vocal cords. Injury results in inability to produce high-pitched sounds.

 

This patient has an isolated inability to produce high-pitched sounds without hoarseness or vocal cord paralysis, which is characteristic of external branch of the superior laryngeal nerve (EBSLN) injury. EBSLN supplies the cricothyroid muscle, which tenses the vocal cords and is essential for pitch modulation. It is particularly vulnerable during thyroid surgery due to its proximity to the superior thyroid artery.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Recurrent laryngeal nerve: Supplies all intrinsic muscles of the larynx except cricothyroid. Its injury typically causes hoarseness, vocal cord paralysis, or aspiration—not selective loss of pitch control.

 

Option C. Internal branch of superior laryngeal nerve: This is purely sensory and supplies mucosa above the vocal cords. Its injury may cause loss of protective laryngeal sensation but not voice changes.

 

Option D. Glossopharyngeal nerve: Supplies the pharynx and posterior tongue sensation. It does not affect laryngeal motor control or pitch modulation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The external branch of the superior laryngeal nerve innervates the cricothyroid muscle and injury leads to loss of pitch control without vocal cord paralysis.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 285

choices.text: Enlargement of left atrium due to mitral stenosis
Compression by a right apical lung tumor
Injury to internal branch of superior laryngeal nerve

questions.text: A 60-year-old man with a history of rheumatic heart disease presents with gradually progressive hoarseness of voice over the past month. Laryngoscopy reveals left vocal cord paralysis. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Enlargement of left atrium due to mitral stenosis

 

This is Ortner’s syndrome—compression of the left RLN by an enlarged left atrium, leading to hoarseness.

 

This patient has left vocal cord paralysis in the setting of rheumatic heart disease—a classic clue pointing toward Ortner’s syndrome, where enlarged left atrium from mitral stenosis compresses the left recurrent laryngeal nerve.
The left RLN takes a longer intrathoracic course, looping under the arch of aorta and passing near the left atrium, making it more susceptible to compression by cardiovascular and mediastinal pathologies.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Compression by a right apical lung tumor: This would affect the right RLN, not the left. The right RLN loops around the right subclavian artery and ascends in the tracheoesophageal groove.

 

Option C. Injury to internal branch of superior laryngeal nerve: This is a sensory nerve to the laryngeal mucosa above the vocal cords and does not cause vocal cord paralysis.

 

Option D. Cricothyroid muscle weakness: This is caused by damage to the external branch of superior laryngeal nerve (EBSLN), leading to pitch modulation loss, not hoarseness due to vocal cord paralysis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The left recurrent laryngeal nerve may be compressed by an enlarged left atrium in mitral stenosis, leading to hoarseness—Ortner’s syndrome.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 285

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with a 3-week history of a breathy, whisper-like voice following thyroid surgery. Flexible laryngoscopy reveals one vocal cord in the cadaveric (intermediate) position, while the other vocal cord is mobile. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Medialisation thyroplasty

 

It is the ideal treatment to improve voice quality by closing the glottic gap in unilateral vocal cord palsy.

 

 

This patient has unilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve (RLN) and superior laryngeal nerve (SLN) palsy, most likely due to iatrogenic injury during thyroid surgery.


When all intrinsic muscles of one side become non-functional, the vocal cord rests in the intermediate (cadaveric) position. Since the contralateral vocal cord is normal, a 3.5 mm glottic gap exists, allowing air escape during phonation. This results in a breathy, whispery voice due to glottic insufficiency.

The treatment of choice is medialisation, which approximates the paralyzed cord toward the midline to allow proper glottic closure during speech.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Total thyroidectomy: Not appropriate here. Thyroidectomy may have caused the RLN/SLN injury; it is not the treatment for resulting vocal cord paralysis.

 

Option B. Botulinum toxin injection: Used for spasmodic dysphonia, not for unilateral vocal cord paralysis.

 

Option D. Radiation therapy: Not indicated unless there is suspicion of a neoplastic cause. This is an iatrogenic neuropathy post-surgery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Unilateral RLN & SLN palsy causes breathy voice due to glottic gap, and is treated by medialisation thyroplasty.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 298

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman undergoes hemithyroidectomy for a benign thyroid nodule. Postoperatively, her voice remains normal with no signs of aspiration. Laryngoscopy reveals one vocal cord in the paramedian position, while the other is fully mobile. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Conservative observation

 

Most cases with this pattern recover spontaneously, and conservative management is sufficient.

 

This case describes unilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve (RLN) palsy, where all intrinsic laryngeal muscles except the cricothyroid (which is supplied by external branch of the superior laryngeal nerve) are paralyzed on one side.
The cricothyroid muscle, being both a tensor and adductor, helps to pull the paralyzed vocal cord medially, resulting in a paramedian position.
Since the opposite vocal cord is normal, it can adequately compensate for the small 1.5 mm glottic gap, allowing normal phonation without aspiration.
Hence, no active intervention is required, and conservative observation is the correct approach.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Immediate medialisation thyroplasty: Not needed. Voice is normal, and there is no aspiration. This is reserved for symptomatic cases (e.g., breathy voice due to larger glottic gap).

 

Option C. Injection laryngoplasty: Unnecessary if voice is normal. This is used when there is glottic insufficiency causing dysphonia or aspiration.

 

Option D. Tracheostomy: Not indicated. Patient has a patent airway, normal voice, and no aspiration.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Unilateral RLN palsy with vocal cord in paramedian position and normal voice is managed conservatively.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 298

questions.text: A 34-year-old professional singer complains of voice fatigue and inability to reach high-pitched notes following a thyroid surgery. She also reports occasional coughing while drinking fluids. On laryngoscopy, the anterior commissure is seen pulled toward the right vocal cord, while the posterior commissure deviates to the left. There is no significant breathy dysphonia. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Unilateral superior laryngeal nerve palsy

 

Explains all features: loss of cricothyroid function, askew glottis, pitch loss, and occasional aspiration.

 

This patient presents with:

 

  • Voice fatigue and loss of pitch control – due to loss of cricothyroid function, the main tensor of the vocal cords.
  • Occasional aspiration – due to loss of sensation in the supraglottic mucosa (above vocal cords), which is normally supplied by the internal branch of SLN.
  • Askew glottis on laryngoscopy – anterior commissure pulled toward normal side, and posterior commissure pointing toward the paralysed side, due to compensatory over-adduction.

 

These findings are characteristic of unilateral SLN palsy, most commonly due to injury to the external branch of the superior laryngeal nerve (EBSLN) during thyroid surgery. Treatment is generally conservative.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Unilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve palsy: Would result in a paralyzed vocal cord in paramedian/intermediate position. Patient typically presents with breathy voice or hoarseness but not selective pitch loss.

 

Option B. Bilateral superior laryngeal nerve palsy: Would cause bilateral loss of tension, more pronounced aspiration and significant voice weakness. Askew glottis is not typically seen.

 

Option D. Psychogenic dysphonia: Typically has inconsistent findings with normal vocal cord mobility on laryngoscopy; not associated with askew cords or aspiration.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Unilateral superior laryngeal nerve palsy causes voice fatigue, loss of pitch, and askew glottis due to cricothyroid weakness, and is managed conservatively.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 299

questions.text: A 60-year-old man underwent total thyroidectomy for carcinoma thyroid. Postoperatively, he is unable to speak, and develops severe aspiration with recurrent coughing during feeding. On laryngoscopic examination, both vocal cords are found to lie in a cadaveric position and do not move or approximate. Which of the following is the best definitive management for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Tracheo-esophageal diversion with permanent tracheostome

 

Gold standard for cases with severe aspiration and bilateral RLN & SLN palsy, preventing aspiration and allowing a safe airway.

 

This patient has bilateral RLN and SLN palsy following thyroid surgery:

 

  • Both vocal cords in cadaveric position: due to bilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve injury.

  • Aphonia: inability to approximate the cords leads to complete loss of voice.

  • Aspiration and pneumonitis: due to bilateral superior laryngeal nerve palsy causing sensory loss above vocal cords.

 

These patients are at high risk of aspiration pneumonia and respiratory complications, and the definitive management is tracheo-esophageal diversion with a permanent tracheostome:

 

  • Trachea is divided at the 2nd or 3rd ring.

  • Upper part is anastomosed with esophagus.

  • Lower part is sutured to skin as permanent airway.

  • Voice is lost, but aspiration risk is eliminated.

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bilateral injection laryngoplasty: This is done in unilateral vocal cord paralysis to medialize the paralyzed cord. Not suitable in bilateral RLN + SLN palsy where airway protection is lost.

Option B. Voice therapy and swallowing rehabilitation: Insufficient in cases with complete loss of airway protection and bilateral nerve involvement.

 

Option D. Type I Thyroplasty: Used in unilateral RLN palsy to medialize the cord. Not appropriate when both cords are paralyzed in abducted position.

Educational Objective:

 

Bilateral RLN and SLN palsy causes aphonia and aspiration, and is managed definitively by tracheo-esophageal diversion with permanent tracheostomy.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 299

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman underwent total thyroidectomy for multinodular goitre. Two weeks later, she presents with inspiratory stridor and dyspnea at rest. Laryngoscopy reveals both vocal cords fixed in the paramedian position. Which of the following is the best immediate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Tracheostomy

 

Indicated immediately in cases of airway compromise from bilateral vocal cord paralysis in paramedian position.

 

This is a case of bilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve (RLN) palsy, in which:

 

  • Both vocal cords are paralyzed in paramedian position due to action of intact cricothyroid muscles (supplied by external branch of SLN).

  • These muscles pull cords medially, leading to life-threatening airway obstruction—a concept known as Wagner and Grossman theory.

 

Immediate management is emergency tracheostomy to secure the airway.

 

If no recovery is observed after 6 months, options for definitive surgical management include:

 

  • Lateralisation thyroplasty (Isshiki Type II)

  • Arytenoidectomy

  • Cordectomy (CO₂ laser)

  • Posterior transverse cordotomy (Kashima's operation)

  • Laryngeal reinnervation procedures

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Type I thyroplasty: Used to medialize paralyzed vocal cords in unilateral RLN palsy. Not appropriate in bilateral palsy with airway obstruction.

Option C. Kashima’s operation: Posterior transverse cordotomy (Kashima) is a definitive procedure for airway improvement but not the emergency step.

Option D. Vocal cord injection with Teflon: Performed to treat glottic insufficiency, not appropriate in bilateral paramedian cord paralysis with stridor.

Educational Objective:

 

Bilateral RLN palsy causes airway obstruction due to paramedian cord position and is managed acutely by tracheostomy.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 290

choices.text: Bilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve palsy; Posterior cordotomy
Bilateral superior laryngeal nerve palsy; Tracheostomy with epiglottopexy
Unilateral RLN palsy; Injection laryngoplasty

questions.text: A 62-year-old male presents with complaints of weak, breathy voice and frequent coughing while swallowing, especially liquids. He has no stridor. Laryngoscopic examination shows both vocal cords are bowed and flaccid. There is no approximation deficit during phonation. Which of the following best explains the condition and its appropriate management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Bilateral superior laryngeal nerve palsy; Tracheostomy with epiglottopexy

 

SLN palsy causes flaccid, bowed cords and aspiration risk due to sensory loss above the cords. Epiglottopexy helps prevent aspiration.

 

This patient presents with classic features of bilateral superior laryngeal nerve (SLN) palsy, which includes:

 

  • Paralysis of both cricothyroid muscles, leading to loss of tension in the vocal cords → bowed appearance and weak, husky voice.

  • Loss of sensation above the vocal cords → increases aspiration risk, especially with liquids.

 

Management includes:

 

  • Tracheostomy to protect the airway.

  • Epiglottopexy to prevent aspiration by stabilizing the epiglottis over the airway during swallowing.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bilateral RLN palsy; Posterior cordotomy: RLN palsy causes airway obstruction due to paramedian cord position and stridor—not seen here. Also, posterior cordotomy is done for airway improvement, not for aspiration.

 

Option C. Unilateral RLN palsy; Injection laryngoplasty: This is done for glottic insufficiency in unilateral RLN palsy with breathy voice—but this case has bilateral symptoms and significant aspiration risk.

 

Option D. Bilateral RLN palsy; Lateralization thyroplasty: This is used when both vocal cords are in paramedian position causing airway compromise—again, not the scenario here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bilateral SLN palsy causes bowed cords and high aspiration risk due to loss of tension and supraglottic sensation; managed by tracheostomy and epiglottopexy.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 291

questions.text: A 24-year-old male with a history of gender-affirming surgery presents requesting voice modulation surgery to help feminize his voice. He has a deep, low-pitched tone and desires a higher-pitched voice to match his gender identity. Which of the following thyroplasty procedures is most appropriate for his condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Type IV thyroplasty

 

Increases pitch by lengthening cords. Suitable for male-to-female transgender voice feminization.

 

 

Isshiki classified thyroplasty procedures into 4 types based on the goal of voice modification:

 

  • Type I (Medialization): Used in unilateral vocal cord paralysis, where the paralyzed vocal cord is pushed medially to improve voice.

 

 

  • Type II (Lateralization): Used in bilateral vocal cord paralysis, to improve airway by lateralizing the cords.

 

 

  • Type III (Shortening): Used to lower pitch (e.g., puberphonia, female-to-male transgender voice deepening), by shortening and relaxing the vocal cords.

 

 

  • Type IV (Lengthening): Used to raise pitch, as in androphonia (deep voice in females) or in male-to-female transgender individuals, by lengthening and tensing the vocal cords.

 

 

In this case, the patient is a male-to-female transgender individual who wishes to raise his pitch. Hence, Type IV thyroplasty is the correct option.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Type I thyroplasty: Used for unilateral vocal cord paralysis. Not indicated for pitch modification in transgender cases.

 

Option B. Type II thyroplasty: Used in bilateral vocal cord paralysis to relieve airway obstruction.

 

Option C. Type III thyroplasty: Shortens the cords to lower pitch, used in puberphonia or female-to-male transgender cases.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Type IV Isshiki thyroplasty increases pitch and is used for androphonia or male-to-female transgender voice feminization.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 301

choices.text: Speech therapy with Gutzmann’s technique

questions.text: A 17-year-old male presents with a persistently high-pitched, female-like voice despite normal development of secondary sexual characteristics. He is emotionally withdrawn and socially self-conscious. On examination, there are no structural abnormalities of the larynx. During Gutzmann’s pressure test, backward pressure on the thyroid cartilage causes a change in voice from high-pitched to low-pitched. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Speech therapy with Gutzmann’s technique

 

First-line treatment in puberphonia. It is non-invasive and often successful.

 

 

This is a classic presentation of puberphonia, a functional voice disorder in adolescent males where voice fails to drop to a lower pitch after puberty despite normal laryngeal anatomy and sexual development.

 

  • The Gutzmann pressure test involves backward pressure on the thyroid cartilage, which loosens the vocal cords and causes them to vibrate at lower frequency, simulating a normal male voice.

  • This helps differentiate puberphonia from structural causes.

  • Initial management is speech therapy, especially using Gutzmann’s technique.

  • Surgery (e.g., Type III thyroplasty, which shortens and loosens the cords to lower pitch) is reserved only if speech therapy fails after 6 months.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Type I thyroplasty: Used in unilateral vocal cord paralysis to medialize the cord, not indicated in puberphonia.

 

 

Option B. Type III thyroplasty: Used to lower the pitch in puberphonia or female-to-male transgender cases, but only after failure of conservative management.

 

 

Option D. Injection laryngoplasty: Used for vocal cord atrophy or glottic insufficiency, not applicable in puberphonia, which is a functional disorder.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Puberphonia is initially managed with speech therapy using Gutzmann’s technique, and surgery (type III thyroplasty) is considered only if it fails.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 302

questions.text: A 22-year-old emotionally sensitive female presents with a sudden inability to speak following a stressful family argument. She whispers while attempting to speak but can cough normally. Laryngoscopy reveals both vocal cords in abducted position with failure to adduct during phonation, but normal adduction during coughing is observed. There is no history of trauma or recent infection. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Reassurance and psychotherapy

 

First-line treatment for functional aphonia. Focuses on the psychological basis of the condition.

 

This patient has functional aphonia (hysterical aphonia), commonly seen in emotionally labile young females. The vocal cords appear abducted during attempted phonation but adduct normally during coughing, proving that adductor function is intact and the disorder is functional (non-organic).

 

  • It typically presents with sudden onset of whispering voice or inability to speak after an emotional trigger.

  • No organic pathology is found on laryngoscopy or imaging.

  • The mainstay of treatment is reassurance, speech therapy, and psychological support or psychotherapy if needed.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Microlaryngoscopic cordotomy: Used for glottic obstruction, not for functional voice disorders like aphonia.

Option B. Injection laryngoplasty: Indicated for glottic insufficiency or vocal fold paralysis, not needed here as vocal fold function is intact.

Option D. Type I thyroplasty: Used for unilateral vocal cord paralysis, not functional disorders where movement is preserved.

Educational Objective:

 

Functional aphonia is treated with reassurance and psychotherapy as vocal cord function is intact and symptoms are psychogenic.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 301
